awd_titl_txt: CAREER:Towards Effective Identification of Application Behaviors in Encrypted Traffic
awd_abstract_narration:
Fabian Monrose
John Hopkins Unversity
0546350
Abstract
Several fundamental security mechanisms for restricting access to
network resources rely on the ability of a reference monitor to
inspect the contents of traffic as it traverses the network.  However,
with the increasing popularity of cryptographic protocols the
traditional means of inspecting packet contents to enforce security
policies is no longer a viable approach as message contents are
concealed by encryption. This project encompasses the first major
component of a principled investigation into the feasibility of
protocol identification based solely on those features that remain
intact after encryption---namely, the packet size, inter-arrival and
direction. More specifically, this work attempts to provide a better
understanding of the limits of protocol recognition based on a
thorough statistical analysis and information theoretic assessment of
the available features in protocol behaviors observed in the
wild. Specifically, this project advances the current state of the art
and contributes to the scientific community by building efficient
mixture models for detecting protocols with multi-modal behaviors,
designing practical tools for visualizing behavioral motifs in TCP
sequences, providing new information-theoretic decision policies for
assigning protocol class labels to these sequences, and imparting new
notions for assessing realistic masquerading attacks and the
appropriate defenses.

por.por_cntn:
To effectively manage large networks, administrators require the ability to characterize the traffic within their network's boundaries in order to diagnose problems, provision capacity, and detect attacks or misuses of the network.  Unfortunately, prior to this award, most approaches for identifying application traffic relied on packet inspection, which can sometimes fail to provide a reliable, or even correct, characterization of the traffic. For one, the information typically used (e.g., port numbers) is determined entirely by the end hosts, and thus can be easily changed to disguise or conceal aberrant traffic.  In fact, such malicious practices are not uncommon, and often occur after an intruder gains access to the network (e.g., to install a ``backdoor'') or when legitimate users attempt to violate network policies.

The work in this project centered on exploring various forms of information leakage that are possible even when traffic is encrypted. In particular, we investigated the extent to which common Internet application protocols remain distinguishable even when packet payloads and TCP headers have been stripped away, leaving only extremely lean data which includes nothing more than the packets' timing, size, and direction.  First, we explored protocol recognition techniques for traffic aggregates where all flows carry the same application protocol.  We then developed tools to enhance the initial analysis provided by these preliminary tools by addressing more specific scenarios.  The methods we developed are useful for estimating the traffic mix on network traces that are believed to contain several distinct protocols, or as a fine-grained way to verify that a set of connections really does contain only a single given application protocol (e.g., FTP).  The techniques developed in this project were also helpful in understanding leakages in encrypted VoIP communications, and that work was subsequently pursued in a new award (1017318). From the perspective of preserving privacy, we also explored novel methods for thwarting statistical traffic analysis algorithms by optimally "morphing" one class of traffic to look like another class.  Through the use of mathematical techniques, we showed how to optimally modify packets in real-time to reduce the accuracy of a variety of well-known traffic classifiers while incurring much less overhead than naive padding.

Lastly, this project culminated with the examination of techniques for filtering so-called opaque traffic, i.e., traffic that is compressed or encrypted. We examine this class of traffic because it incurs particularly high overhead for deep packet inspection engines and often yields little or no useful information. Our real-world experiments showed than an overwhelming majority of payload-carrying TCP packets are opaque, forcing the security community to consider the challenges this class of traffic presents for network security, both in the short-term and, as the proportion of opaque traffic continues to rise, for the future.  We provided a first step toward addressing some of these challenges by introducing new techniques for accurate real-time winnowing, or filtering, of such traffic based on the intuition that the distribution of byte values found in opaque traffic will differ greatly from that found in transparent traffic.  Evaluation on traffic from two campuses reveals that our techniques are able to identify opaque data with high accuracy, while examining less than 16 bytes of payload data.  We implemented our most promising technique as a preprocessor for the Snort IDS and compared the performance to a stock Snort instance by running both instances live, on identical traffic streams, using a Data Acquisition and Generation card deployed within a campus network.  Our results showed that our ability to apply more rules to the transpa...
